resources.string: In this module, we will dive into one of the core concepts in computational linguistics and formal grammar. Parse trees play a crucial role in the world of syntax, allowing us to break down and understand the structure of sentences and expressions. Whether you\'re new to parsing or have some experience, this lesson will help you build a solid foundation in constructing and interpreting parse trees.

Parse trees, also known as syntax trees, represent the syntactic structure of a string according to a given grammar. Each node in the tree represents a grammar rule, and the leaves of the tree represent the terminal symbols (the actual elements of the input). Parse trees are essential in compilers and natural language processing as they enable us to check the correct structure of input data based on a set of grammatical rules. The construction of a parse tree involves starting from the root (the start symbol of the grammar) and working through the production rules until the input is fully parsed.
Mathematical Expression Parsing: For the expression 3 + (4 * 5), the parse tree would break it down into:
Two branches: one for the number 3 and another for the multiplication 4 * 5
Sentence Parsing in English: For the sentence "The cat sleeps," a simple parse tree would look like:
The root node represents a sentence (S).
Branches for noun phrase (NP: "The cat") and verb phrase (VP: "sleeps").
The noun phrase further breaks down into a determiner (Det: "The") and a noun (N: "cat").
